entry.et: Middle English, from Old English rāp; akin to Old High German reif hoop

def.dt: :a large stout cord of strands of fibers or wire twisted or braided together
:a long slender strip of material used as rope rawhide rope
:a hangman's noose
:lariat
:a row or string consisting of things united by or as if by braiding, twining, or threading
:special or basic techniques or procedures show him the ropes
:line drive
:in a defensive and often helpless position
:to bind, fasten, or tie with a rope or cord
:to partition, separate, or divide by a rope rope off the street
:lasso
:to draw as if with a rope :lure
:to take the form of or twist in the manner of rope
:ski tow 1
:a rope used for exercises and children's games that involve jumping over the usually twirling rope each time it reaches its lowest point
:a game played with a jump rope
:a rope formed wholly or chiefly of wires

entry.et: Middle English skippen, perhaps of Scandinavian origin; akin to Swedish dialect skopa to hop

def.dt: :to move or proceed with leaps and bounds or with a skip
:to bound off one point after another :ricochet
:to leave hurriedly or secretly skipped out without paying their bill
:to pass over or omit an interval, item, or step
:to omit a grade in school in advancing to the next
:misfire 1
:to pass over without notice or mention :omit skipped her name
:to pass by or leave out (a step in a progression or series)
:to cause to skip (a grade in school)
:to cause to bound or skim over a surface skip a stone across a pond
:to leap over lightly and nimbly
:to depart from quickly and secretly skipped town
:to fail to attend or participate in skip the tournament skip the meeting
:to jump bail
:to use a jump rope (as for exercise or a game)
